notes:
1. Concept

Buckling is a failure mode characterized by a sudden sideways deflection of a long, slender structural member subjected to a high compressive axial load. This can occur even if the compressive stress is less than the material's yield strength. It is a failure due to instability.

2. Euler's Column Formula

The Euler formula calculates the critical load ($P_{cr}$), which is the maximum axial load that a long, slender, ideal column can carry without buckling.

$$ P_{cr} = \frac{\pi^2 EI}{(KL)^2} $$
  • $P_{cr}$ is the critical buckling load.
  • $E$ is the modulus of elasticity of the material.
  • $I$ is the minimum area moment of inertia of the column's cross-section.
  • $L$ is the unsupported length of the column.
  • $K$ is the column effective length factor, which depends on the end support conditions.

3. Effective Length Factor (K)

The K-factor accounts for how the column is supported at its ends. Different end conditions change the column's ability to resist buckling.

  • Pinned-Pinned: K = 1.0 (The baseline case).
  • Fixed-Fixed: K = 0.5 (Strongest case).
  • Fixed-Pinned: K = 0.7.
  • Fixed-Free (Cantilever): K = 2.0 (Weakest case).

solvedExamples.question: For a slender column, which set of end conditions will result in the highest critical buckling load?

options.text: Fixed at one end, free at the other.
Fixed at one end, pinned at the other.

solvedExamples.explanation: The critical load is inversely proportional to the square of the effective length factor, K ($P_{cr} \propto 1/K^2$). The lowest K-factor will give the highest critical load. The fixed-fixed condition has the lowest K-factor (K=0.5), making it the most resistant to buckling.
